claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.

verified_evidence.quote: because it is not subject to mutations to the A (H3 N2) glycosylation binding site that reduce the effectiveness of egg based vaccines.
verified_evidence.explanation: The quote 'because it is not subject to mutations to the A (H3 N2) glycosylation binding site that reduce the effectiveness of egg based vaccines.' appears on page 6 of the document. The wording matches the provided quote, and the factual content is preserved.. The quote directly states that egg-based vaccines are subject to mutations at the A (H3N2) glycosylation binding site, and that these mutations reduce their effectiveness. This explicitly supports the claim that cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness, at least for egg-based vaccines. The quote does not mention cell-based vaccines, but it does substantiate the risk of mutation and reduced effectiveness in egg-based vaccine production as claimed.
